sn22.89:1.1: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
sn22.89:1.2: Now at that time Venerable Khemaka was staying in the Jujube Tree Monastery, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.89:1.3: In the late afternoon those senior mendicants came out of retreat and addressed Venerable Dāsaka,
sn22.89:1.4: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:
sn22.89:1.6: hope you’re keeping well; they hope you’re all right. They hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.’”
sn22.89:1.7: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He went to Khemaka and said to him:
sn22.89:1.9: hope you’re keeping well; they hope you’re all right. They hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
sn22.89:1.10: “Reverend, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”
sn22.89:2.1: Then Dāsaka went to those senior mendicants and told them what had happened. They said,
sn22.89:2.4: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:
sn22.89:2.6: these five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:
sn22.89:2.7: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.89:2.8: Do you regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self?’”
sn22.89:3.1: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:
sn22.89:3.6: “These five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:
sn22.89:3.7: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.89:3.8: I do not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self.”
sn22.89:4.1: Then Dāsaka went to those senior mendicants and told them what had happened. They said:
sn22.89:4.6: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:
sn22.89:4.8: these five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:
sn22.89:4.9: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.89:4.10: If, as it seems, Venerable Khemaka does not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self,
sn22.89:4.11: then he is a perfected one, with defilements ended.’”
sn22.89:5.1: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:
sn22.89:5.6: “These five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:
sn22.89:5.7: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn22.89:5.8: I do not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self, yet I am not a perfected one, with defilements ended.
sn22.89:5.9: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.”
sn22.89:6.1: Then Dāsaka went to those senior mendicants and told them what had happened. They said:
sn22.89:7.1: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:
sn22.89:7.3: when you say “I am”, what is it that you’re talking about?
sn22.89:7.4: Is it form or apart from form?
sn22.89:7.9: When you say “I am”, what is it that you’re talking about?”
sn22.89:8.1: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:
sn22.89:8.10: “Enough, Reverend Dāsaka! What’s the point in running back and forth?
sn22.89:8.12: I’ll go to see the senior mendicants myself.”
sn22.89:9.1: Then Venerable Khemaka, leaning on a staff, went to those senior mendicants and exchanged greetings with them.
sn22.89:9.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. They said to him:
sn22.89:9.3: “Reverend Khemaka, when you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?
sn22.89:9.4: Is it form or apart from form?
sn22.89:9.9: When you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?”
sn22.89:9.10: “Reverends, I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to form, or apart from form.
sn22.89:9.11: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling …
sn22.89:9.15: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.
sn22.89:10.1: It’s like the scent of a blue water lily, or a pink or white lotus.
sn22.89:10.2: Would it be right to say that the scent belongs to the petals or the stalk or the pistil?”
sn22.89:10.4: “Then, reverends, how should it be said?”
sn22.89:10.5: “It would be right to say that the scent belongs to the flower.”
sn22.89:10.6: “In the same way, reverends, I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to form, or apart from form.
sn22.89:10.7: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling …
sn22.89:10.11: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.
sn22.89:11.1: Although a noble disciple has given up the five lower fetters, they still have a lingering residue of the conceit ‘I am’, the desire ‘I am’, and the underlying tendency ‘I am’ which has not been eradicated.
sn22.89:11.2: After some time they meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.
sn22.89:11.3: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
sn22.89:11.7: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the disappearance of consciousness.’
sn22.89:11.8: As they do so, that lingering residue is eradicated.
sn22.89:12.1: Suppose there was a cloth that was dirty and soiled, so the owners give it to a launderer.
sn22.89:12.2: The launderer kneads it thoroughly with salt, lye, and cow dung, and rinses it in clear water.
sn22.89:12.3: Although that cloth is clean and bright, it still has a lingering scent of salt, lye, or cow dung that had not been eradicated.
sn22.89:12.4: The launderer returns it to its owners, who store it in a fragrant casket.
sn22.89:12.5: And that lingering scent would be eradicated.
sn22.89:12.6: In the same way, although a noble disciple has given up the five lower fetters, they still have a lingering residue of the conceit ‘I am’, the desire ‘I am’, and the underlying tendency ‘I am’ which has not been eradicated.
sn22.89:12.7: After some time they meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.
sn22.89:12.8: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the disappearance of form.
sn22.89:12.12: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the disappearance of consciousness.’
sn22.89:12.13: As they do so, that lingering residue is eradicated.”
sn22.89:13.1: When he said this, the senior mendicants said to Venerable Khemaka,
sn22.89:13.2: “We didn’t want to trouble Venerable Khemaka with our questions. But you’re capable of explaining, teaching, asserting, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing the Buddha’s instructions in detail.
sn22.89:13.3: And that’s just what you’ve done.”
sn22.89:14.2: Satisfied, the senior mendicants approved what Venerable Khemaka said.
sn22.89:14.3: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty senior mendicants and of Venerable Khemaka were freed from defilements by not grasping.
